Author: jansako#3330
Content:
I run a few of tests I wanted to share & maybe get a little feedback:

- I found a pool that does auto-coin switch & payout in BTC.
- I put a NH order for about 30% less than the pool's listed profitability (the lower of estimated or actual)
- Once the order run out of money (usually 2-3 days, total about 24 hours hash time) I checked the results. 
- After 4 tries in 3 different pools I found that I have mined about 50% of the hash cost (a 0.005 NH order mined ~ 0.0025 BTC) Exception - I caught that megablock in zpool yesterday so at least I got my BTC back)
- Doing the same as above in a Pirate pool returned almost exactly (within 1-2 %) the expected amount of coin (Network hash/my hash x 100 x block reward x number of blocks for the order duration)

Author: jansako#3330
Content:
On the face of it, I would expect to turn at least a small profit when buying hash  30-50% cheaper than the stated 'profitability' of the pool...

What gives?

Author: jansako#3330
Content:
The 2 obvious answers are:
- my not understanding math, or missing something
- the pool operators misleading the miners about 'real' profitability
- NH misleading the buyers about the hashrate they actually provide - does not seem likely considering Pirate hash was repeatedly spot on

Author: jansako#3330
Content: Sorry for the wall!

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: @jansako The main thing to remember is that the hash you rented is assumed to *already be* part of the network when you run it through a calc

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: So, there will always be a disparity there

Author: jansako#3330
Content: not sure what you mean

Author: jansako#3330
Content: If I am renting a 'general' Equihash hash, then directing it to a specific pool, how can that hash be in that pool before I send it there?

Author: jansako#3330
Content: BUT if my hash is already part of the network, then the calc based on that network hash should be more accurate, not less

Author: jansako#3330
Content: I was thinking of PPLNS - related losses as well cause (cheap) NH hash is unstable, so I picked pools with high hashrate that get blocks often

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content:
OK, lets say you want to rent 10M sols.
When you put that 10M into a calculator, the calculator does not *add* that 10M to whatever "network hashrate" and/or the resulting "difficulty" of adding that amount of hash
If you already had that 10M running and the calc *did* account for it, there are other factors (not limited to other miners joining, luck, etc) that determine actual vs theoretical results
----
Sadly, there is no calc in the world that is accurate, and even less than that are even close when it comes to KMD (which would throw off any math of using a pool like zpool)

Author: jansako#3330
Content: I see the issue with renting a massive hash (especially short time)

Author: jansako#3330
Content: What I did was specify a max 0.1 MSol, to large pools that mine multiple coins. Usually the incoming hash to my workeds was going to 3-4 coins at the same time

Author: jansako#3330
Content: My hash was never more than 1-2% of the pool's hash

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content:
The larger the network is will be the more any given amount is "accurate" in a calc
When swinging 100k even, coin network size can matter greatly
What all coins where these pools mining?

Author: jansako#3330
Content: Here is an example from zpool: https://imgur.com/a/5KxchpX

Author: jansako#3330
Content: I also user zergpool, but that one closed a few days ago 😦

Author: jansako#3330
Content: also 'miningpoolhub' which mostly switches between zcash, zencash or zcalssic

Author: jansako#3330
Content: I also tried SHA 256 which has a ton of coins & hashrate, as you can imagine

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content:
Specifically, a pool like zpool *can* have the opposite of intended results from time to time
If you hit a run of bad luck, it's entirely possible that you only hit blocks from low-diff coins and when you switch to the high-diff coin(s) you get nothing and then later switch back to a low-diff coin and have a share that would have been of block find diff on the high-diff coin (you may need to reread that, I don't know how else to phrase it)

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: luck plays a huge factor in mining

Author: jansako#3330
Content: Understood. Need no more proof that I gotten a part of that mega block (which ended up bringing me to the expected results overall). Trouble is that  it seems to me that one was an outlier.

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content: Also, if you did a run for a year, rather than a day, the result would likely be much closer to "expected" because of the law of averages

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content:
`(usually 2-3 days, total about 24 hours hash time)`
Another thing that I just thought of, it's possible that many block finds happened while you weren't submitting shares and thus you didn't get paid "fully" for that period (due to a lowered share %age)

Author: jansako#3330
Content: Yeah, I thought about the PPLNS thingie... figured 30% cost/proceed difference coupled with the high block frequency of a large pool would cover that

Author: jansako#3330
Content: I would almost have to run another test with a 'fixed order'

Author: jansako#3330
Content: those suckers are expensive though

Author: jansako#3330
Content: Or find a pool that only does PPS

Author: ComputerGenie 👴🏼📢#7004
Content:
As near as I can tell, NH doesn't misrepresent hash by any meaningful amount.
The share-diff that they use can screw you based on a block diff actually being lower than their min diff, though

Author: jansako#3330
Content: Yep, it would have shown up clearly on the Pirate test for sure

Author: jansako#3330
Content: Gotta run, time to pick up the little one from school, thank you for looking at this with me sir!

Author: Jules - coinblockers.com#8043
Content:
Dear Miners,
I'm happy to announce that we have activated the hot suggested minimum payment feature for all our Pool coins.
This will help to alleviate the Bitcoin's inherited issue for wallet address which constantly receiving massive of flow of low-amount coins (due to mining) which in-turn affecting the wallet address'  UTXO sending out allowance.
This also can be useful if you wish to send your mine proceed directly into Exchange's wallet address, although we discourage you to do this for your own security (if don't own the private key, you are not owning the wallet).
Here's how to do it:
If you want to get paid from 20 coins, add this value into your password field of your mining software:
payfrom=20  
or any float value if you like such as:  payfrom=20.5
